segments.text: This is Tuesday, March 23, 1976.
I'm Mark Burnett, and I'm working on an oral history project for Dr. Kimber's cultural geography class.
I'm talking with Mr. Harry L. Kidd, Jr. Mr. Kidd is an associate professor of English and the assistant dean of the graduate college at Texas A&M University.
Mr. Kidd, I guess we'll start out you telling us a little bit about your background.
All right, I'll be happy to, Mr. Burnett.
I'm of German, Welsh, and Italian stock.
My grandfather on my mother's side was descended from one of the Hessian soldiers of the American Revolution who remained in the United States after the Revolution.
My grandfather's name was J.W.W.
Schuller, and he was a mountain circuit rider.
in the southwestern part of the state of Virginia.
He was a Methodist circuit rider, and he and his entire family were devoted Methodists.

Two of his sons were Methodist preachers, and one was rather noted during the so-called Roaring Twenties as Fightin' Bob Shuler, who was a famous West Coast evangelist and who was constantly in the newspapers for his attacks.
on sand and the devil, and I think also on Amy Semple McPherson, who was a rival evangelist lady at the time.
My father's people were early settlers in Virginia.
They were of Welsh stock, and they settled in the little town of Lovingston, Virginia, which is not far from Charlottesville.
My grandfather Kidd, his name was Edward Kidd, was clerk of the court there in Lovingston for many years.
My father was a law graduate of Washington Lee University in Virginia.
One of his brothers was a VMI graduate, and the other was a University of Virginia graduate.
And you can well imagine that there was a good old football rivalry up in that part of the woods.
Sometimes it was said the kid boys couldn't stay in the same house with each other during the fall football season.
I myself was born in a small mountain town in southwest Virginia, a little town called Lebanon, Virginia.
It was the county seat of Russell County.
My father at that time was a young lawyer.
He was a partner in a very old law firm specializing in corporation law.
Lebanon was, I thought, a very beautiful little town.
I loved it very much.

It was a mountain town completely surrounded by mountains on all sides with springs coming out of the sides of the mountains and all beautiful rhododendrons and flowers of all sorts on the sides of the mountain in the springs.
And there were caves in virtually every small hill and mountain where little boys who liked a little adventure in danger could play.
And there was some danger.
But of course, our parents didn't find out that we'd been in some of these caves until we got home again and we had trouble.
My family was composed of my father and mother, myself, and Ed Kidd, my younger brother.
Ed was named after my grandfather, Edward Kidd.
Ed now lives in Mahea, Texas.
He is retired having had a serious illness a few years ago.
I went to school in Lebanon.
It was an interesting school.
It was a small mountain school in which for the first few grades, several grades were taught in one room.
I don't remember now all these years later too much about my early school experiences.
I do remember that we had chapel every day and we had a very
traditional, I suppose, conservative American-type chapel of the 20s in these small schools.
We all filed in.
In fact, we marched in the chapel.
Everyone in the school marched in the chapel and took seats in the same places every morning.
We had prayers led by the school superintendent, something that wouldn't be allowed now.
And we sang various songs.
I can remember such songs as America the Beautiful,
when the corn is waving any deer, and other songs that all of us really enjoyed singing.
Generally, either the school superintendent or some prominent person in town would give us a little inspirational talk.
There would be announcements made about the work of the day, and then we'd all go back to our rooms and work.
I enjoyed my school life there.
It was pleasant.
It was a small town.
I had a number of good playmates.
In the wintertime, snow was on the ground from about October until March.
We could go up into the sides of the mountains and take our little flying arrow sleds and slide down the mountains.
I well recall trying my sled out in an early autumn snow.
And the snow was just fine for sledding, but there was a little brook at the bottom of the mountain that I'd forgot about.
And I was just flying down the side of the hill and suddenly realized that there it was.
And it had not frozen over, and there was nothing to do.
I just stayed with the sled.
sled and I went into about four feet of icy cold water, and that ended my sledding for the day.
We had lots of fun in the summertime.
My aunts and uncles who also lived around the town there had cherry trees and fruit trees of various kinds.
I spent a good deal of time sitting up in cherry trees, making myself sick with cherries.
In the fall and autumn, we had apple trees of various kinds in our own backyard.

I well remember the cider making operations that we used to involve ourselves in and the way the bees and wasps would get drunk on the cider and crawl around and fall into the cider and have to be strained out.
We had various things in the yard there.
We had a garden, which I didn't care too much for because I had to do a little work in it that I didn't much want to do.
I raised ducks and turkeys and rabbits and so forth, and there they were mainly pets, and I felt bad when we ate one, though I ate my share nevertheless.
So all in all, life in this little mountain town was very pleasant for me and for my family and for all those people.
I knew there it was a small and fairly prosperous town.
It was not far from the coal mine area, but it wasn't a coal town.
Basically, it was a farming town and a tobacco town.
It was also the county seat.
And all of the trials of the county were there.
And it was the headquarters for most of the lawyers of the area.
At age 12, when I was 12, my father's health became bad.
And he was advised to move to a climate that was somewhat warmer in the wintertime.
And because we had relatives in Texas, my grandfather, Schuller, having left the Holston Conference sometime before and having
joined the Central Texas Conference as a Methodist preacher, we decided to try Texas.
And my father came to Texas first, and after a year sent for us, and he had settled in Mejia, Texas in Limestone County.
I was 12 years old when we came to Mejia.
My brother was three and a half years younger.
It seemed to me that the transition from life in
the little mountain town of Lebanon to life in my head was perhaps harder on me than it was on anybody else, at least I felt that way about it.
I was leaving all my friends, I was leaving my baseball team and my buddies, and I didn't know anybody.
It was a completely new area, new school, new state, new type of people.
I just felt totally out of place and miserable there in my head when I came there.
At the time,
that I moved there in 1927, Mahale was a dying oil town.
It had at one time been the largest oil field in the world.
Mahale-Wortham Field combination was the biggest oil field in the world.
Produced more oil than any other known oil field up to that time.
But the field was dying, the companies were pulling out, some of the rigs were left, and they were pumping.
And I well remember the first few nights that I slept in our
new house that my father had built for us there in Maham.
I kept hearing this steady drumming sound and I didn't know what it was.
There wasn't anything like that up in the mountains where I'd come from.
And I, after some days, possibly even weeks, when the sound just filled the air at night and you could still hear it in the daytime, I got upnerved enough to ask somebody what it was.
And it turned out to be the pumping of the
the rigs out in the field five or six miles from Mahea.
At night you could hear this sound for miles and it was very distracting to someone who was not used to it.
In time I got used to it, paid no attention to it at all, but it was interesting.
My father's health problems had pretty well strapped the family financially and
We had barely got well settled in Mahea until the Great Depression hit.
And this was, of course, a very bad economic time for everybody, including lawyers in the new area.
There wasn't much money coming in.
And I thought that I ought to find work and make what I could.
So I suppose I was perhaps 14 or 15 when, maybe a little earlier, when I first started taking every known job that I could get paid money.
I did all sorts of things.
mowed yards, chopped cotton, which was a rather difficult job and paid fairly well, but it was a very grueling job.
I picked cotton.
I well recall picking cotton for a dollar a hundred for a full summer.

and it takes a whole lot of cotton to in a week's time at a dollar a hundred to bring your paycheck up to fifteen or twenty dollars you're you're working from dawn to dark but I really enjoyed cotton picking perhaps more than any other job that I did because there was a friendship and a camaraderie among the pickers the black and white working together we told stories swapped yarns as we moved down the rows and the fast pickers were very kind they'd help

me, teach me how to pick a little more, a little faster, and at lunchtime we'd pull our cotton sacks up under the wagon out of the sun and eat our sandwiches or lunches and crack a coke if we had one and generally enjoy ourselves.
It was hard work but it was in a way very rewarding work and I enjoyed the summers that I spent, two or three of them, picking cotton.
Meantime, of course, I was back in the
small domestic livestock business there at home.

I had two milk cows of my own and sold milk in the neighborhood and I raised rabbits which I dressed and had a good market for both the furs which I shipped off and the meat to restaurants there in town.
I had a very regular killing schedule and delivery schedule and made pretty good money out of the rabbits and pigeons and other things that I had.
I never would
work with anything or handle any type of livestock that I could not make pay for itself because I simply couldn't afford to.
And I suppose I was rather, what shall I say, I was tight with a dollar then.
I still am to some extent because these hard times made me feel that money was a very valuable commodity if you could get it some way or other.
I enjoyed my school life after I got to high school.
I was out of place pretty much the first year or two in the last two grades of elementary school, simply because I didn't know anybody.
But in a couple of years, I managed to get on the softball team there.
And I began to take up tennis and proved to be quite a good tennis player.
And so by the time I got into high school, which was only three years in those days, I had a number of friends, both boys and girls, and people to play with.
And I was on the softball team, and I was both the singles player and on the doubles team for the high school in tennis for three consecutive years.
Twice I went to state meet.
I didn't win anything, but at least I did.
get by the district and got to state meet and had the fun of going and so on.

I was also on the high school debating team, which gave me a number of bad speech habits which I never was able to overcome, one of which was, of course, talking much too fast under any sort of pressure situation in order to be able to make all the points I felt that I had to make as a debater.
However, my partner and I, Sam was my partner.
He and I were very successful debaters for a couple of years.
And we also went to state meet and debate.
And I recall at one of the state meets,
I was in the unfortunate situation of having an important debate called at the same time a tennis match was called.
The only thing I could do was forfeit one of them, and I chose to forfeit the tennis match because I felt we might have a better chance in debate.
We lost the debate match, but I think I would have also lost the tennis match, so I really didn't lose very much.

I graduated from high school in 1932 and had managed to save up enough money from my summer's work and also from a newspaper route that I had carried for several years there in Mahea and from the profits from my small livestock operations to at least see my way to one year and possibly two of college or university.
I wanted to go to Washington Lee, where my father had gone, and study law.
But this seemed out of the question, because it was a long way away, and the tuition costs and so forth in those days were comparatively high as compared to the local schools in Texas.
So in the end, I did what many other people did.
Mr. Burnett, who is sitting here and looking rather questioning, is a Texas Aggie, and I rather hate to tell him that I decided to opt to go to the University of Texas at Austin.
This I did.
I went down to the University of Texas and I went early with the idea that perhaps if I went a little early in the fall I could find a job somewhere in Austin and make my money go a little further.
Well, I was very lucky.
I hadn't been

in Austin very long at the university I was over at the in front of the registrar's office one day when a lady came in from down in the valley somewhere I just remember now just where she was from but she was a very nice lady and she was bringing her son to put him in school at Austin as a freshman he too was going to be a freshman and I had been there a few days and knew where things were so I just happened to meet the son and
talking to him.
He didn't know where to go, so I volunteered to show him and his mother around for half a day.
After I had done this for about four hours, I was getting along very well with both the boy and his mother.
They were very, very nice people.
They seemed to like me, and I certainly liked them.
She asked me if I'd have lunch with them, and I was happy to do this.
And while at lunch, she asked me if I would like to work for her.
She was going to open a boy's boarding house.
She already had the boarding house there.
And she was going to open this boarding house.
And my job was to be to try to recruit students who came to the university to live in the boarding house and then sort of help her manage the house after it was full.
For this, I was to get a room and my meals.
This sounded very good to me, and I accepted the job with gratitude.
and managed to do this.
In fact, in about ten days I had the room full of students, the house full of students.
Most of them were freshmen and they had made their deposits and Mrs. Jones, who was the lady, was very, very happy and I was happy and I did, in fact, work for her for a couple of years there.
So I got off to a good start in my life at college.
I had not
thought too much about what I'd like to major in, but had changed my mind from thinking about law largely at my father's urgings.

He had not been happy in the legal business, although he had made a good deal of money in Virginia, but he had never really liked the law, I think, and he kept insisting that this was not a good profession for me to follow, though I thought really that it was, and I still think perhaps I might have made a good lawyer.
In any case, I decided that I would study chemical engineering.

I think the reason was that some of the engineering older students at Texas wore boots and little riding pants tucked into their boots, and they looked very virile and masculine and experienced and worldly, and I thought, my, it would be nice to be an engineer.
Perhaps I, too, would be an engineer.
So I majored in chemical engineering, or at least declared for it.
I did fairly well in the coursework the first year, but I was not particularly interested in it.
And I disliked mechanical drawing or drafting very much indeed.
I had a teacher, unfortunately, who taught me something that I've thought about many years in my own teaching experience.
He had absolutely no patience with my early efforts, and I had a slight tremor in my right hand, and I couldn't join the
lines as accurately as he would like for me to join him.
I could read blueprints and was good enough in theory, but I simply could not draw very well.
And he would come up in front of the class and take my drawings and make all manner of fun of them and criticize them and tell me I could never be an engineer.
So after a while, I rather decided whether I could be an engineer or not.
If this was an engineer, I didn't want to be one.
And so I gave up the engineering profession and switched
than to mathematics, in which I had done quite well.
I stayed with mathematics a while.
And then in my third year, and I, of course, was working through the summers, it looked as though I might graduate someday in mathematics.

I had also taken a number of education courses so that I might be qualified to teach if I chose to do so, though I had for a time thought of working as a mathematician for an oil company or perhaps an actuarial service for an insurance company, something of this sort.
In any case, meantime I had met the girl that I was going to marry.
there in Texas.

She was a Miss Minnie Lee Canterbury of Clarksville, Texas which is one of the oldest towns in the state and she was a pure English descent and a very beautiful girl and much to my happiness and pleasure she seemed to like me very much and I certainly fell in love heavily with her and by the time I was within about a year of possible graduation we were talking about marriage plans
And we're seeing each other every day after class and so on, a typical college romance, I guess one would say.
So I switched to an English education major because I knew I could graduate quickly and thought that I could probably get a job.
This I did.
That is, I did, in 1935, graduate with an AB degree in English and a minor in education.
However, jobs weren't as easily come by as I'd thought they were.
I had taken a job in the last six months or so while I was still a student before graduation selling adding machines on commission in Austin.
I was walking up and down the street trying to sell adding machines to small commercial businesses.
My machine was a 10 key machine.
I believe, if I recall rightly, it was an old Remington.

In any case, I was not the world's greatest adding machine salesman because though I'd done all sorts of things, I was always a little hesitant about walking into a perfect stranger and taking up his time trying to present a product, trying to sell things to him.
And I have never forgot some advice that the typewriter man for the Austin firm gave some of us juniors one time.
He knew what a struggle we were having and also how important it was to us to be able to sell and make our commissions because we were working on a straight commission basis.
A good commission, but commission only if you sold a machine, of course.
What he said was something like this.

He said, I know just how you young people feel about walking into a tired, harassed businessman and asking him for his time and trying to sell him a machine that maybe you feel he might not need or he can't pay for or what have you.
But he said, I want you to think about it like this.
When that man gets up in the morning, he puts on his pants one leg at a time, just like you do.
He's a human being.
You have a good product.
Now, I would say just remember this fact.
We're all human.
And walk in there and present your product because you're actually doing him a favor.
If you can sell him the product, it will pay for itself in a very short time in his business.
You're doing him a favor, you're doing yourself a favor, and you're doing the American economy a favor.
You made a real inspirational speech.

So the next day, next morning when I started out, the first thing I thought of when I came to my first prospect's place of business was about that remark about the man's putting on his pants one leg at a time.
And I could just see him getting up and doing it.
Somehow this relieved me of a great deal of tension.
And I sold three machines that day and seemed to have very little trouble selling the machines thereafter.
I didn't sell a great number, but I sold enough to
make enough commission to see that I would be able, easily enough, to support myself, if necessary, as an attic machine salesman.

I did not really want to do this, however, and just before school started in the fall of 1935, the placement office at university called me in and said they had heard of an opening at Anderson, Texas, a small town, the county seat of Grimes County.
Now, I had
Struggled all summer long and back into the spring trying to find a job teaching for that is what I wanted to do.
I must have written over a hundred letters of application to various places in which I heard there were openings or which the placement office told me there were openings.
But very few of these were answered because I had no experience and many experienced teachers were out of jobs and school people could pick and choose.
They could hire anyone they wanted to.
I even walked eight miles to a little country school from the nearest bus.

I walked there at four o'clock and left four o'clock in the morning and walked eight miles to the superintendent's house thinking I would be the first person to be interviewed for a simple teaching job.
I found five experienced people, men with families, waiting on the porch when I got there around six o'clock.
And I was so discouraged that I simply caught a ride with the mailman back to the bus stop and came back to Austin.
There was obviously no chance for me to be hired.
However, this job in Anderson had come open at the very last minute.
It came about in an odd way.
The young man who had been principal there for several years had somehow or other got on the, shall I say, the wrong side of the high school boys whom he taught and whom he coached.
And they had thrown him out of a second-story window of the high school, breaking his right arm, fracturing his collarbone, and doing a few other bits of damage to him.
It was a rather rowdy group, shall I say.
And when he came to in the Navasota Hospital, his first vow was, I'll never go back in that school again.
And he didn't.
Thus left the job open.
I was told this in advance, but of course I wanted a job desperately, and I decided to go over and interview for the job.
I will not forget that interview.
It was a rather interesting one.
It was held in a fine old farm home built almost 100 years prior to the fall of 1935 on the outskirts of Anderson.
The home belonged to an old gentleman named Neblett, N-E-B-L-E-T-T, who, as I recall, was president of the school board.
And the board held its meeting to interview me for the job and to interview one other teacher for an elementary teaching job in his living room.
When I went in, there was the board, Mr. Neblett and Mr. Wilson.
I can remember Mr. Vic Borski and one of the finest men who ever lived, who was the local blacksmith and a grand person.
Mr. Jennings, Dr. Emmy Parker, another grand person.
In fact, they were all real fine people.
But some of them were outstanding to me as the years went by.
Of course, I didn't know any of these people then.
They looked very forbidding.
little over 19 years old, soaking wet, and weighed about 130 pounds.
And I had very little hope of getting the job.
However, I was encouraged somewhat to note that there were no other applicants in the room except me and the young lady who was to be interviewed for a grade school position.
So I was called before the board in its wisdom.
And Mr. Neblett carried on most of the questioning.
He asked me about my background, my credentials, what I had done, my college work and so on, whether I was married and so forth and so on, all of which seemed to satisfy him well enough.
And then Mr. Jennings came up with the $64 question.
He said something like this, well, Mr. Kidd, your credentials are good enough, but you're mighty small, and that's a rough bunch of boys.
Can you discipline them?
I said, what?
He said, can you discipline them?
I said, well, I'm not exactly sure what you mean.
If you mean, can I whip them?
I can't, obviously, neither individually nor collectively.
But I said, I can teach them, and I don't think I'll need to discipline them physically.
I said, I have a feeling I can get along with them very well.
And he just frowned and shook his head, and I thought, well, there goes at least one vote.
But Dr. Parker and some of the others seemed to like what I had said, and they asked me to go out of the room and wait a while while they decided on my fate, whether I should be employed or not.
And I spent 15 or 20 minutes in considerable suspense and then was called back in the room, and Mr. Neblett told me that I was hired in a most interesting way.
He said, well, Mr. Kidd, we've decided to hire you because we haven't got any other applicants, but I'll tell you, you'll never make it.
With this happy thought, I accepted the job and went to Anderson.
and a rather interesting sort of job.

I was to be the principal of the high school and also the principal of the elementary school, and combined in one job, I was to teach mathematics, shop, general science, and to coach basketball, baseball, track, and tennis.
I was also to assist the secretary of the school board, and for this work, I would be paid $80 a month on a nine-month basis.

Well, $80 a month was not bad money, really, in those days, even for nine months, because the apartment that I was able to rent, a small upstairs apartment for my wife and myself, cost $10 a month, bills paid.
Eggs were something like $0.08 or $0.10 a dozen, bread, a nickel a loaf.
I had a dog, and I could feed my dog more.
good neck meat, soup meat, fresh cut by the local butcher for a nickel a day than we can now buy for a dollar.
Things were cheap, and the $80 proved to go a long way.
I didn't feel bad about that.
I went into this job with some degree of trepidation, not knowing what I would find, but what I did find was four of the happiest and most rewarding years of my life.
I made wonderful friends there I never had.
I can honestly say that I never had the slightest trouble with any of the high school boys or the girls.
They were a serious, dedicated, hardworking, and hard-playing bunch of young people.
They were divided into three ethnic groups.
There were Germans, Poles, and what they referred to as Americans.

The reason this ethnic division took place was the fact that a German, a body of Germans had settled in the community, had established the Lutheran Church, and had a parochial school of its own up through the seventh grade for many years prior to the time I came there.
Also, a group of Poles had settled in the community.
They were fine farmers, and they had established a Catholic church and had a Catholic parochial school, also for many years prior to the time I'd gone to Anderson.
The other people were so-called old families who referred...
